image.altText: Daniel Andrews announces Commonwealth Games cancellation

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms the state will no longer host the 2026 Commonwealth Games due to cost blowouts. Follow live.

title.children: Commonwealth Games bodies slam Victorian government's decision to walk away from hosting duties

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was a little hesitant to say too much about the Games cancellation, preferring to focus on events that were actually going ahead. "That's a decision made by the Victorian government. I'll leave the Victorian government to go through those details," he said of the news this morning. "But I'm certainly focused on a sporting event that will happen in two days time with the Matildas and I think that the whole of Australia will be cheering them on, with the opportunity that we have of hosting the World Cup here." "The World Cup is the third largest sporting event held in the world, only beaten by the men's football World Cup and the Olympic Games. And we're hosting it, we're hosting the Olympics in south-east Queensland, of course, in 2032. And Australia has a fine record of hosting events."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese responds to Games cancellation

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was a little hesitant to say too much about the Games cancellation, preferring to focus on events that were actually going ahead.
"That's a decision made by the Victorian government. I'll leave the Victorian government to go through those details," he said of the news this morning.

"But I'm certainly focused on a sporting event that will happen in two days time with the Matildas and I think that the whole of Australia will be cheering them on, with the opportunity that we have of hosting the World Cup here."

"The World Cup is the third largest sporting event held in the world, only beaten by the men's football World Cup and the Olympic Games. And we're hosting it, we're hosting the Olympics in south-east Queensland, of course, in 2032.
And Australia has a fine record of hosting events."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The premier has been asked why the Games couldn't have been held in Melbourne, rather than cancelled altogether? He says the government has "looked at every option". "We have looked at every conceivable option. All of them are far in excess of the $2.6 billion that's been budgeted, so all of them represent more cost than there is benefit, and on that basis none of those options stack up and we're not going to be hosting the Games in 2026." He said many of Melbourne's competition-grade facilities were "fairly busy". "So there is a cost so we would not be using them, and there is also the small matter of you could save money by not building villages for instance, but then every hotel room in the city would be pretty much taken up by those who are part of the Games, not those who are coming here to watch the Games. "So again the cost-benefit ratio does not stack up."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: So why not just move the Games to Melbourne?

children.content: The premier has been asked why the Games couldn't have been held in Melbourne, rather than cancelled altogether?
He says the government has "looked at every option".

"We have looked at every conceivable option. All of them are far in excess of the $2.6 billion that's been budgeted, so all of them represent more cost than there is benefit, and on that basis none of those options stack up and we're not going to be hosting the Games in 2026."
He said many of Melbourne's competition-grade facilities were "fairly busy".

"So there is a cost so we would not be using them, and there is also the small matter of you could save money by not building villages for instance, but then every hotel room in the city would be pretty much taken up by those who are part of the Games, not those who are coming here to watch the Games.
"So again the cost-benefit ratio does not stack up."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government is committed to improving sporting facilities across regional Victoria and says the planned upgrades that were to accompany the Games will still go ahead. That includes upgrading Eureka Stadium in Ballarat to seat 10,000 spectators and upgrades to Bendigo Stadium.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional sporting facilities to be upgraded

children.content: The government is committed to improving sporting facilities across regional Victoria and says the planned upgrades that were to accompany the Games will still go ahead.
That includes upgrading Eureka Stadium in Ballarat to seat 10,000 spectators and upgrades to Bendigo Stadium.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rabobank says Russia's withdrawal from a UN brokered grain deal with Ukraine means global grain prices will be volatile. The deal saw more than 32 million tonnes of Ukrainian grain exported to 45 countries over the past year through its Black Sea ports. Rabobank senior grains analyst Dennis Voznesenski says grain prices have been on a rollercoaster since the agreement expired overnight as the market “attempts to decodify the impact on international trade flows”. “The main question will be whether Ukraine continues to export through the Black Sea without the safety of the grain corridor. "Prices will continue to be volatile until the market is able to decipher the end impact,” he said." Mr Voznesenski says Ukraine has been building up alternatives to its Black Sea grain ports, but they can't fully compensate for the loss of port access. “More than 40 per cent of Ukraine’s grains and oil seeds exports moved through the grain corridor in recent months, with the remainder moving over road and rail into eastern Europe and through the Danube river system." "The Danube river system export capacity has been increasing substantially since the war started, but more expansion will take time.” He also says the expiry of the deal could affect Russia's grain exports. “Any exemptions that Russia was given by the West in return to signing up to the grain corridor will likely become void, possibly slowing its export abilities."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rabobank says grain prices on 'rollercoaster'

children.content: Rabobank says Russia's withdrawal from a UN brokered grain deal with Ukraine means global grain prices will be volatile.
The deal saw more than 32 million tonnes of Ukrainian grain exported to 45 countries over the past year through its Black Sea ports.

Rabobank senior grains analyst Dennis Voznesenski says grain prices have been on a rollercoaster since the agreement expired overnight as the market “attempts to decodify the impact on international trade flows”.
“The main question will be whether Ukraine continues to export through the Black Sea without the safety of the grain corridor.
"Prices will continue to be volatile until the market is able to decipher the end impact,” he said."
Mr Voznesenski says Ukraine has been building up alternatives to its Black Sea grain ports, but they can't fully compensate for the loss of port access.

“More than 40 per cent of Ukraine’s grains and oil seeds exports moved through the grain corridor in recent months, with the remainder moving over road and rail into eastern Europe and through the Danube river system."
"The Danube river system export capacity has been increasing substantially since the war started, but more expansion will take time.”
He also says the expiry of the deal could affect Russia's grain exports.
“Any exemptions that Russia was given by the West in return to signing up to the grain corridor will likely become void, possibly slowing its export abilities."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Yindjibarndi traditional owners in the Pilbara in north-west Western Australia have formed an energy corporation with Philippines listed renewable energy developer ACEN. The Yindjibarndi Energy Corporation plans to build one of Australia's biggest renewable energy projects with 3 gigawatts of capacity. YAC chief executive Michael Woodley said the deal provided employment, training, and ongoing revenue opportunities. "We actually initiated this whole structure ... we said we wanted to be part of renewables, so we went and set up a business called Yiyangu that's 100 per cent owned by the Yindjibarndi people," he says. The Yindjibarndi are fighting Fortescue Metals in the Federal Court for compensation for mining on their country. ACEN has more than 8 gigawatts of projects in Australia and recently opened the first stage of a solar farm project near Uralla in New South Wales. Here's more from Peter de Kruijff from ABC Pilbara.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yindjibarndi sign renewable energy deal

featuredLink.title: Multi-billion-dollar renewables project earmarked for Yindjibarndi native title land

children.content: The Yindjibarndi traditional owners in the Pilbara in north-west Western Australia have formed an energy corporation with Philippines listed renewable energy developer ACEN.
The Yindjibarndi Energy Corporation plans to build one of Australia's biggest renewable energy projects with 3 gigawatts of capacity.
YAC chief executive Michael Woodley said the deal provided employment, training, and ongoing revenue opportunities.
"We actually initiated this whole structure ... we said we wanted to be part of renewables, so we went and set up a business called Yiyangu
that's 100 per cent owned by the Yindjibarndi people," he says.
The Yindjibarndi are fighting Fortescue Metals in the Federal Court for compensation for mining on their country.
ACEN has more than 8 gigawatts of projects in Australia and recently opened the first stage of a solar farm project near Uralla in New South Wales.
Here's more from Peter de Kruijff from ABC Pilbara.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian market has extended its losses in midday trade after the release of the RBA minutes. The ASX 200 is down nearly 0.5 per cent with real estate, consumer stocks, miners and energy firms weighing on the market. Meanwhile banks are leading the gains. Banks get more income when interest rates rise. Rubber gloves maker Ansell (-14.5 per cent) has tumbled after it said it would slow production and cut manufacturing jobs next year to improve cashflow. Reuters says an internal memo from Lendlease shows it plans to cut around 740 jobs globally.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market lower at midday

children.content: The Australian market has extended its losses in midday trade after the release of the RBA minutes.
The ASX 200 is down nearly 0.5 per cent with real estate, consumer stocks, miners and energy firms weighing on the market.
Meanwhile banks are leading the gains.
Banks get more income when interest rates rise.
Rubber gloves maker Ansell (-14.5 per cent) has tumbled after it said it would slow production and cut manufacturing jobs next year to improve cashflow.
Reuters says an internal memo from Lendlease shows it plans to cut around 740 jobs globally.
